perturbation.original_text: Within three business days of receiving Application Provider's written update, Excite@Home will remove any advertising from Application Provider's listed competitors displayed on the Co-Branded Pages.
perturbation.changed_text: Within ten business days of receiving Application Provider's written update, Excite@Home may remove advertising from Application Provider's listed competitors displayed on the Co-Branded Pages, subject to Excite@Home's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a clear deadline of three business days for removing competitor advertising. The modified text extends the deadline to ten business days and introduces uncertainty by making the removal discretionary. This contradicts typical advertising agreements where timely removal of competitor ads is crucial and often legally mandated for fair competition.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 17200 (Unfair Competition Law) - could be construed as unfair competition if Excite@Home unreasonably delays removing competitor ads, potentially harming Application Provider's market position.

perturbation.original_text: Within ten (10) days of the Effective Date of this Agreement, e-centives shall make a non-refundable payment to Excite@Home of $***** as pre-payment for Payment-Eligible User Data records:
perturbation.changed_text: Within forty-five (45) days of the Effective Date of this Agreement, e-centives shall make a non-refundable payment to Excite@Home of $***** as pre-payment for Payment-Eligible User Data records:
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires payment within ten days of the agreement's effective date. Changing this to forty-five days introduces a delay in payment, which could be a breach of contract if it violates standard payment terms or creates financial hardship for Excite@Home. The initial payment is typically for upfront costs.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Breach of Contract (Delay in Payment). Although no specific statute is directly violated, delaying payment can be a breach if the original 10-day period was crucial for financial obligations or if the delay results in damages.

perturbation.original_text:
Within forty-eight (48) hours of receiving notice that a Program Member has opted out of first-party contact, Application Provider shall:

       i)   Ensure that future emails to the Program Member do not contain                any Excite@Home branding; and

       ii)  Ensure that future emails do not direct the Program Member to the                Co-Branded Application. Application Provider may continue to                direct Program Members to http://www.e-centives.com or its                subsequent replacement.
perturbation.changed_text:
Within seventy-two (72) hours of receiving notice that a Program Member has opted out of first-party contact, Application Provider shall:

       i)   Ensure that future emails to the Program Member do not contain                any Excite@Home branding; and

       ii)  Ensure that future emails do not direct the Program Member to the                Co-Branded Application. Application Provider may continue to                direct Program Members to http://www.e-centives.com or its                subsequent replacement.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the opt-out compliance time from 48 to 72 hours impacts user privacy, because 48 hours for removing a user from the company's email list is already short. This change will allow the company to send potentially unwanted emails during an additional day.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Online Privacy Protection Act (CalOPPA) requires websites to have a privacy policy, if a user is opting out for privacy reasons, giving a longer time period could be seen as violating that act.
